results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a series of scenarios based on a question which is also the title of the reel: ‘Where is it?’ and features Kenneth’s son-in-law Bob Wootton as the person looking for the answer and responding to each segment. Kenneth has Bob look in a book from a bookshelf which contains the hand written sequence titles. Kenneth also uses both black and white and colour sequences to add to the more dramatic feel of the reel. Kenneth has Bob pondering the title questions through the sequences as well as laughing at the end of some. the reel ends with Bob laughing uproariously.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:57:00 first colour scenario begins with title ‘Mr McCraw’s Orchids’ showing us Mr McCraw among his orchid plants in a hothouse as well as Kenneth’s favoured individual shots of individual blooms.

00:02:29:00 we see the next sub title, ‘Eastern Beach Geelong’ followed by colour footage of children playing in the water, foreshore recreational equipment such as diving boards and waterwheels, piers and crowds on the boardwalks and swimmers in and out of the water.

00:05:18:00 several yachts appear in the sea in what could be a race.

00:05:44:00 Bob opens the book again to the sub title ‘Skating at St Moritz’ followed by a colour sequence of a large scale ice skating show involving multiple performers and skotches at St Moritz, (presumably) in Melbourne’s St Kilda.

00:07:45:00 starts with the sub titles, ‘Hobbies - What is yours? Is it Model Boats?’ with Bob gazing toward footage of some intricate model boats and ships sailing and steaming around a shallow (and what appears to be purpose built) pool. The pool is surrounded by older children who appear to be operating the models.

00:14:52:00 Bob reveals the next question ‘or is it Model Trains?’. Here Kenneth shows us a group of men who operate model trains on a track raised high enough from the ground that they are able to ride the trains which seem to operate by steam.

00:18:21:00 ‘Or is it like mine - The Camera?’. Here we see a man in a park with what looks like a ‘box brownie’ camera taking pictures of seemingly random women (though we have seen one of them in other reels).

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film features a school for children with special needs. We see the children undertaking classroom activities and hear interviews with the teachers.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:09:00 children sit on the floor ready to play musical instruments followed by views of the children enjoying playing with the instruments
00:00:32:00 interview with a teacher discussing the lessons children are involved in that day
00:01:50:00 one of the teachers addresses the camera directly to discuss future plans for the school
00:02:24:00 the children take part in a shopping expedition
00:02:36:00 painting at easels
00:03:49:00 activities with the grocery items bought earlier
00:04:14:00 individual lesson in shopping for a teenager

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 35]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film follows the club meetings of the ‘Victorian Sporting Car Cub’, in 1956 to Fisherman’s Bend and Albert Park in Melbourne, Templestowe in outer Melbourne and Hepburn Springs in regional Victoria. Cars are are regular feature in Kenneth’s films and this film certainly shows viewers many wonderful models from the era. The film inlcudes Reg Hunt who would become one of Australia’s best racing car drivers.

Among the racing audiences we see Mrs Rankine, daughter Bettye Rankine and her husband Bob Wootton, with their young son watching the races and having a car-side picnic.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title card ‘For Some Real “Hurry Up” Join the Vic. Sporting Car Club’
00:00:22:00 program brochure for ‘Fisherman’s Bend Classic Airstrip Races’ followed by cars rounding a bank of hay bales
00:

00:00:00:00

00:04:17:00 onlookers in grass at Fishermen’s Bend.
00:00:47:00 brochure for the Hepburn Hill Climb 1956.
00:08:15:00 brochure for Moomba Motor Races.

results.title: Mallacoota fishing trip
results.brief_description:
Mallacoota - There is boatloads of nostalgic charm in this short black and white 1950s film of men taking a fishing trip at Mallacoota. Photographer Athol Adams has captured a sense of fun in this footage, made more entertaining to modern eyes because of the formal clothes the fishermen are wearing. A wonderful glimpse of a different generation at play.
Athol Adams footage is courtesy of Jenny and Owen Peake.

results.title: The Queen Mother at Essendon Airport
results.brief_description:
Silent footage of the arrival on 27 February 1958 of the Queen Mother at Essendon Airport to a welcoming crowd of waving spectators, military parades and marching bands, and government officials and dignitaries. Filmed by portrait photographer Athol Adams.
Athol Adams footage is courtesy of Jenny and Owen Peake.

results.title: Fred's Films. [Luna Park] [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Filmed in the mid 1960s by steam train enthusiast and home movie maker Fred Daley who captures a family outing to the popular sea-side amusement park in St Kilda. ‘Luna Park’ is shown in all its summertime glory with the ‘River Boats’, the ‘Dodgems’, the ‘Rotor’ (a washing spin cycle for humans!), ‘The Spinner’ and of course its famous wooden roller coasters, the ‘Big Dipper’ and the ‘Scenic Railway’. Courageous Fred even films during the ride where you catch a glimpse of Port Phillip Bay from the very top!

results.title: Mongrel's funeral
results.creator_credit: Peter Maguire, Australian Film Commission and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A small country community is drawn together by the death of “Mongrel” in an accident. But it’s not until his mates gather in the pub in their “Sunday best” to bolster their courage for the funeral, that they are able to express their real sorrow. Conveniently missing the church service, they give Mongrel a send-off in their own way. Cast includes Sheila Florance, Reg Evans, Charlie Sandford, Neil Robbins, Andrew Klipple, Neil Modra, Alec Maguire and Keith Johnson. (Award: Winner Diploma of Merit, Melbourne Film Festival 1987)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Maguire, Australian Film Commission and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures the Rankine/Woottons holidaying at Gosford, NSW coast.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:05:00 up to this point, footage of a train travelling over a causeway from the mainland which can be identified as the Gosford area on the NSW coast.

00:00:06:00 - 00:00:18:00 panoramic footage being filmed from a vantage point above and where we see the Wootton family relaxed and on holidays as illustrated by their innovative footwear for the time: rubber thongs which were first produced in Australia by Dunlop in 1959.

00:00:19:00 to 00:00:44:00 footage of the bays and the town (presumably Gosford).

00:00:45:00 a prolonged shot of the three Wootton children looking more grown up and confident in front of the camera.

00:01:02:00 the family gather around what is likely to be a metal map on a pedestal for tourists.

00:01:45:00 footage is taken from a higher vantage point again at and includes a shot of fellow tourists at 00:01:52:00.

00:01:55:00 ‘Ploddy the Dinosaur’ (erected 1963) at the Australian Reptile Museum and Sanctuary at Gosford where we see snakes, lizards and other species in enclosures.

00:02:42:00 the family feeding tame kangaroos and cockatoos.
.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film shows an outing to the local horse races, a visit to a fast flowing river and some street scenes in Ballarat in the 1940s.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 horses racing on a country race track
00:00:35:00 racing official on horseback
00:00:51:00 ‘S E Chamberlain’ bookmaker bag is sighted in the background while an older gentleman in a three piece suit and hat ambles past the camera
00:01:10:00 a group of women at the races wearing hats including a scarf knotted at the front in a 1940s style
00:01:22:00 a man gestures to the camera that he has lost his bet
00:02:01:00 advertising sign for ‘Longhurst Quality Bread’
00:02:15:00 a travelling tram, tram tracks, cars and trucks on Ballarat streets, including Sturt Street
00:02:25:00 a service station called Atlantic Garage
00:02:30:00 two men walking around a turbulent waterway
00:03:03:00 Ballarat rooftops from a high vantage point
00:03:50:00 Ballarat street scene focussing on some people walking toward the camera wearing good examples of fashionable 1940s style clothes
00:04:08:00 Ballarat Town Hall
00:04:10:00 a main shopping street in Ballarat showing a ‘Myer Store’ verandah

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film contains street scenes in Bendigo, a drive to the Tambo River in Gippsland Victoria, looking for mushrooms in a farm paddock, some spectacular hairstyles and wonderful 1940s clothes.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:23:00 a tram moves along a street with shops in the background in Bendigo
00:00:34:00 glimpse of a ‘Bendigo’ advertising sign on a building
00:00:40:00 palm trees and a lake in the Bendigo Botanic Gardens
00:00:57:00 sign for ‘Bendigo Bitter Beer’ on a building
00:01:07:00 cows in a slightly hilly paddock and then a house on the hill
00:01:45:00 a car parked on a bridge and a river before the sign ‘Tambo River’
00:01:47:00 a small group of a child, two women and an older man who appears to be a farmer climbing through a wire fence into a paddock. The farmer uses the old method of a foot holding down the lower fence wire and a hand holding up the top wire for his companions to get through the gap comfortably
00:02:14:00 as the women are holding baskets we can presume the group are in the paddock to collect mushrooms; the women both have wonderful, thick curly hairstyles
00:02:30:00 the camera is filming from inside a car travelling down a country road
00:02:47:00 a scene at the races where two women are surprised by and smiling at the camera
